titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. We rode all Night, with the weather severely cold, and the wheels dragging heavily through the Snow, and the runs. We did not arrive at Baltimore, untill past 9. this morning— Both the Stages for Washington had gone between 6 and 7. O’Clock— I wished to have gone out of town to see Mr: and Mrs: Buchanan; but was so fatigued and so unwell that I could not accomplish it— Pass’d the day at Gadsby’s, late Evans’s tavern— Wrote to my wife, and to Mr: Peck— Lost my watch, and had it brought back to me again in the Evening. I had written an advertisement of it, for the newspapers, but though I have owned it more than seven years, I had never remarked the makers name, and the number.— (It is Leslie— London N. 712.)— Mr: Calhoun paid me a visit this afternoon, and sat with me, about an hour.

2. I went to bed last Night, not very well— But about 2. O’Clock this morning I waked, very sick at my Stomach, and otherwise very much disordered— Continued so with little intermission, untill I was called, for the Stage—about 6. O’Clock— I was then so sick, and faint, as to be scarcely able to dress myself— I hesitated for some time, whether to venture myself in the Stage this day, or to postpone the remainder of my journey untill to-morrow— I concluded however finally to make the exertion— But for an hour after I got into the Stage was unable to hold up my head— At the Elk-ridge landing I was obliged to quit the Stage, and walk about a mile; to cross the river on the ice.— After this, I found myself better— Breakfasted at Spurrier’s; and having very good roads arrived, about 4. in the afternoon at Mr: Hellen’s in Washington— In the Evening, I called for half an hour at Mr: Boyd’s, where I found Mr: de Cabre. Mrs: Johnson also was there, and with her I came home; overpowered with fatigue, and want of sleep.

3. After a quiet Night, I determined to allow this day for repose, and did not quit the house— Mr: Bacon called upon me; as did also Mr: Stackpole, of Boston— And I received a letter from Mr: Peck, with a line also from Mr: Granger— Employed the day principally in writing; but without any advancement of my business.

4. Visited the President, Mr: R. Smith the Secretary of the Navy at his Office, Genl: Turreau, and Mr: Erskine— Mr: Madison came in while I was at the President’s, and also while I was at Mr: Smith’s Office— I also called at Mr: Boyd’s— Dined and pass’d the Evening at home.

5. Mr: Anderson, Mr: Giles, Mr: Thruston and Mr: Cook called this morning to visit me, and I was engaged in conversation with them untill dinner-time— Dined at Mr: Boyd’s— Adelaide Johnson went with me; but did not return at Night. Mr: T. French, and a Mr: March were at Mr: Boyd’s, in the afternoon and Evening.— My whole day from before noon untill nine at Night was engross’d to my irreparable injury— I wrote a little in the Night— Received a letter from my wife.

6. I visited this Morning Mr: Madison, and Messrs: Cook, Bacon and Storer— Found Mr: Giles with Mr: Madison— Of the other Gentlemen, Mr: Cook only was at his lodgings— I attended at the opening of the Session of the United States Supreme Court—held at Long’s tavern; formerly Stelle’s on the Capitol-Hill— The Chief-Justice (Marshall) and the Judges Washington, Livingston, and Cushing only attended. They called over some cases, and declared their intention to proceed on the trials to-morrow— I saw Mr: Cranch, and delivered him the letter from Mr: Amory— Mr: Rodney, the Attorney-General mentioned that he should decline arguing the Cause, and should employ some other person— I called on Mr: Otis at his Office— In the Senate chamber, where I saw several of the members, and I went for a few minutes into the gallery of the House of Representatives, where I heard Mr: J. G. Jackson speaking.— I dined with Judge Anderson at his lodgings— Mr: Gregg and Mr: Leib— General Helms and Mr: Rhea of Tennessee were also there— In the Evening I pass’d an hour at Mr: Boyd’s; which brought it to the close of the day; and being unwell, I could not set up late in the Night— And thus another day, is lost.

7. Attended the Session of the Supreme Court; where two or three short causes were argued— Mr: Bacon called on me while in Court, to have some further conversation relating to public affairs; which we had— I examined the files in Mr: Otis’s Office— Found some additional papers, and reference to some others— Dined, and passed the Evening at home, employed as I should be— If I can but so persevere!

8. Attended the Court, where a Cause from the Circuit Court of Pennsylvania was tried, and took up the day— I returned a few visits, and was for about a quarter of an hour in the galleries of the House of Representatives; where the two Houses of Congress were convened, and were counting the votes for President and Vice-President— Mr: Madison is elected to the first of these Offices, and Mr: Clinton is re-elected to the second— I called at the Office of the Secretary of the Treasury, on a letter from Dr Waterhouse, which I received last Evening— But he was not there— Evening at home, much engaged— I received a letter from my friend J. Gardner, informing me of the death of his wife.

9. At the Court the Cause of Boardman and Pope against the Providence Insurance Company was called, and Mr: Ingersoll opened it on the part of the Company— He took very unexpectedly an objection to the Jurisdiction of the Court; because one party is a Corporation, and not described as Citizens of the State of Rhode Island— But he also argued the question upon the merits of the case— I dined with Mr: Cranch—looked into a few books cited by Mr: Ingersoll—came home early in the evening, and was employed untill very late, in attempting to methodize an answer to Mr: Ingersoll.

10. Mr: Lloyd and Mr: Quincy called upon me this forenoon. Attended Court— I answered Mr: Ingersoll, upon the point to the Jurisdiction; but declined arguing the case upon its merits, untill the Court should decide this first point— The next cause was one in which the Bank of the United States was a party— And in which the same question whether a Corporation, could be a party in the Courts of United States was made— Mr: Binney of Philadelphia made upon it one of the handsomest arguments I ever heard delivered— The ground which he took was entirely different, and in some particulars opposite to mine— And he supported it with admirable eloquence— The effect upon the audience and upon the Court was great— I called for a few minutes at the gallery of the House of Representatives— They were debating a bill proposed by Mr: Dana— I dined and pass’d the Evening at home— Mr: Hellen’s youngest child is very dangerously ill.

11. I attended again the Supreme Court— Mr: Key and Mr: Walter Jones, argued the question against the Bank of the United States, and Mr: Ingersoll closed the argument on the part of the Bank— This occupied the day— I pass’d the Evening at home. Mr: Hellen’s child continues at the point of death— Dr: Jones was here with Dr: Patterson to attend it.

12. Mr: Duvall the Comptroller of the Treasury, and a Mr: Ridgley of Baltimore called this morning to see me— As did Mr: Parker, a member of the Senate and Genl: Storer of the House of Representatives, from New-Hampshire— I took a walk about the middle of the day, and called at Mr: Boyd’s—he was abroad— The remainder of the day and Evening I was at home, in closest application to my business— I consider it as business of the first necessity and duty.

13. Attended the Supreme Court again— I applied to the Court for permission to be heard, on the argument respecting the right of Corporations to sue or be sued in Courts of the United States; as it respected the interest of Mr: Cushing— They said they would hear me— Mr: Boardman and Mr: T. K. Jones have arrived, and were this day in Court— Evening again closely engaged— My eyes are suffering, but my duties to the utmost of my power must be performed— Mr: Hellen’s child is still at extremity—though now with some favourable symptoms.

14. The Court were engaged the whole day in a Cause of Insurance from Alexandria, which they left unfinished— They all dined at Mr: Madison’s— I received also an invitation, but it had been four or five days left for me at Stelle’s bar, and receiving it so late, I could not go— I sent an apology by judge Livingston— Evening busy at home— Mr: Hellen’s child is better.

15. The Alexandria insurance cause engaged the Court again the whole of this day— It was further argued by Mr: C. Lee, and by Mr: W. Jones— After the Court adjourned, I went into the galleries of the House of Representatives and heard the close of a warm speech of Mr: D. R. Williams— Evening at home employed as usual.

16. The Court this morning called up in course the Cause of Fletcher and Peck— Mr: Martin on the part of Fletcher was not prepared— The Court after some hesitation agreed to postpone it untill another day— I went into the Library and examined some books— Dined with the Judges, and some other Gentlemen at Mr: Caldwell’s— Mr: Quincy met me and gave me information that my Mother has been very ill— Which increases my anxiety at being so long without hearing from home— I read something this Evening, and found an opinion of Judge Jay, much to my purpose.

17. As the Court in some sort engaged not to call up the case of Fletcher and Peck this week, and as the weather was bad, I pass’d this day in my chamber, excepting a walk about noon, when I called upon Mr: Granger and at Mr: Madison’s Office, in search of some documents which I was however unable to obtain— I also returned Mr: Duval’s visit, but he was not at home— I received this day a melancholy letter from my wife.

18. Attended the Court for about half an hour this day— And pass’d a couple of hours in the Congress Library; examining books— I returned home from the Capitol with Mr: Key—Mr: Dana—and Mr: Livermore— The remainder of the day; morning and Evening I was engaged in my chamber— Eliza Johnson, who has been here while Mrs: Hellen’s child has been so ill, went this morning home to Mr: Boyd’s.— Mr: Harper spoke to me about his fee.

19. Walking towards the Capitol I met Mr: Kelley and Mr: Vandyke, and afterwards Mr: Van Rensselaer, members of the House of Representatives, who mentioned some accounts of recent success of the French in Spain— I called for about half an hour at Mr: Boyd’s— Remainder of the day and Evening, engaged as usual.

20. Attended the Court— Mr: Harper argued the question respecting the Jurisdiction of the United States Courts in cases when corporations are parties— The Court offered to hear me, but I was not prepared— There were some silly reports in circulation, for an hour or two this morning, which almost every body believed— I dined at the President’s— The Judges Washington, Johnson and Livingston were there— The Chief Justice and Judge Cushing absent— When I went I found Mr: Jefferson reading newspapers—he said one of his greatest enjoyments was to think he was about to be released from the necessity of reading them at-all.— In the Evening I pass’d half an hour at Mr: Boyd’s— Mr: Hellen dined at Mr: Erskine’s.

21. Heard in Court a Cause from Kentuckey argued by Mr: Pope; after which it was discovered that the parties were not averr’d upon the record to be Citizens of different States—a Question was made whether by common consent an order of Court might be made for inserting the averment— They determined that they would make no order of Court, however it might be done by the consent of the parties— Some other business was then taken up— I went over to the Capitol to see Mr: Quincy, who I heard had late Letters speaking of my dear Mother’s illness— They were two days later than mine, but gave me no later information— I heard Mr: G. W. Campbell and Mr: Randolph, differ about the meaning of Letters of Marque and Reprisal.— I then called in at Mr: Otis’s Office, and had some conversation with Mr: Bradley suggesting some new ideas relating to my Cause in Court— I went into the Senate and heard the close of a Speech by Mr: Hillhouse against the Non-intercourse bill— It pass’d however 21. to 12— Coming home I walk’d part of the way with Mr: Hillhouse and Mr: Pickering—and Mr: De Lohre— Evening in my chamber.

22 After attending at the Court, and hearing an argument from Mr: Pope, I went into the Library of Congress, and looked over some Books. Dined at Mr: Boyd’s— There were Balls at Georgetown and in the City, this Evening; in honour of Washington’s birth day— Mr: Hellen and the Ladies attended that in the City— I pass’d the Evening at home.

23. Mr: Pope and Mr: Rowan were again arguing Causes in Court. Mr: Cranch asked me to dine with him, in company with several gentlemen of the Bar— I excused myself however, from the obligation to attend upon my business— The same reason prevented my attendance in the Evening, upon a party at Dr: Thornton’s, to which the Ladies went.

24. The Court this morning called up the case of Fletcher and Peck; but Mr: Martin not being in Court, and not being ready, they agreed to take up one other cause before it; but gave notice that they should then call it again, and it must be either argued or continued— We were ready, and I stated that I should as far as I was able insist upon having a trial at this term. The case which was immediately after taken up occupied the day, and will probably employ one or two more— Evening at home— Mr: De Cabre, Mr: De Lohre, and Mr: Texier were here part of the Evening— I was a short time in the House of Representatives where they were debating on the question of striking out the 4th: of March as the day for removing the Embargo.

25. The Cause in Court, yesterday commenced was resumed and employed this day without being finished— I dined at Mr. Erskine’s with a small company of Gentlemen— Several members of the house did not come; the house having continued very late in Session— On this account we sat down late to dinner— And I did not rise from table untill 10. at Night— Mr: W. Penn also remained untill that time— There was a party this Evening at Judge Duckett’s to which the Ladies went: and to which I received an invitation in the Evening— But I stayed at Mr: Erskine’s untill it was too late.

26. Attended church this morning at Georgetown, and heard Mr: Addison— The Ladies went with me— Dined with Mr: Crawford of Georgia, at his lodgings. Mr: Hellen also dined there. And two of the Judges—Livingston and Johnson— We came late home—

27. The Court were again engaged the whole day, on the cause with which they were occupied on Friday and Saturday— It is now drawing to a close, and our case comes next— I have continued to make all the application to it in my powers

28. The cause of Hepburn and Dundas against Colin Auld is still before the Court, and employed them all this day— My attendance to it is constant; but I employ the time there in pursuing the investigation of my own cause— Some doubts have been express’d by the Court this day, whether they would take it up at-all— Judge Washington has scruples about sitting in the case; and Mr: Harper intimated to me a probability that the other judges would be divided in opinion.— Dined at home with a company of gentlemen— Among whom were Mr: Giles, Crawford, Anderson, and Harper— Messrs: Delort— Texier, & De Cabre pass’d the Evening here.

Day. I rise about 7.— Read or write in my chamber untill 9. Breakfast— At 11 or 12 walk to the Court-house—a room in a tavern on the Capitol-hill—attend in Court usually untill about 4 in the afternoon— Walk home to dinner— Evening in my chamber, engaged usually untill midnight— Sometimes untill one or two in the morning.
